blog.name: unlevelplayingfield
blog.title: Unlevel Playing Field
blog.description: A sports-related blog curated by final year Sports Education students at Nottingham Trent University

summary: Should athletes be allowed to take performance enhancing drugs in sport?
title: Should athletes be allowed to take performance enhancing drugs in sport?
body:
From Thomas Hicks use of drugs during sporting events to Tyson Gay’s failed drug test. The question is should athletes be allowed to take performance enhancing drugs in sport?

Performance enhancing drugs (PED) are substances well known to improve the performance and form of athletes.

An obvious example of this would be doping. Doping is when athletes take illegal substances to improve their performance.

There are several types of performance enhancing drugs such as; Androgenic agents like Anabolic steroids, Stimulants and Diuretics. 

Stimulants usually improve athlete’s alertness and aggressiveness. Anabolic Steroids are known to increase athletes muscle mass and strength, which allows athletes to perform and train better. Diuretics are substances that help change the body’s natural balance of fluids and help remove fluids from the body which can disguise other drugs which have been consumed.

So, should athletes be allowed to use PEDs?

Drugs in the Olympics

The use of performance enhancing drugs in the Olympics is nothing new. The first case of strychnine doping dates back to the 1904 Olympics Games, where athlete Thomas Hicks won the marathon after being injected with strychnine in the middle of the race.

The first official ban on ‘‘stimulating substances’’ by a sporting organisation was introduced by the International Amateur Athletic Federation (IAAF) in 1928. It was not until 1967 when the International Olympic Committee (IOC) banned the use of performance enhancing drugs and created a list of substances which were banned.

Since the banning on PED’s, more natural talented athletes such as Jamaica’s Usain Bolt have broken world records and ran in faster times than athletes who have consumed PED’s. This shows that athletes don’t need to consume PEDs in order to succeed and training hard is more effective than using illegal substances to create an unfair advantage and improve performance.

If Bolt can create history more than once without the use of PED’s, then all athletes are capable of reaching their maximum potential without the use of PED’s.


In 2013 USA’s Olympic athlete Tyson Gay pulled out of the 100M Sprint at the Moscow World Championships due to testing positive for a banned substance. Gay failed three drug tests which led to the athlete being stripped of his silver medal won at the London 2012 games along with his fellow relay teammates and Gay being banned for a year.

Likewise, in 2010 Tour de France winner Alberto Contador was found guilty of doping. After two years of investigating he was found guilty of consuming Clenbuterol, which is a fat burning and muscle building supplement. This led to the Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas) banning Contador for two years and being stripped from his 2010 victory.

A more up to date and relevant issue surrounding drugs in sport was in 2014, where The International Olympic Committee stated “Russian athletes are considered to be affected by a system subverting and manipulating the anti-doping system.” This resulted in The International Paralympic Committee (IPC) banning the entire Russian Federation from competing at the 2016 Rio Paralympics.

To summarise, I believe that athletes should not be allowed to use performance enhancing drugs. Why? Other than the fact that it is cheating and creates an unfair advantage over natural athletes, there are also too many incidents where athletes’ careers have been ruined and medals being stripped due to the use of PED’s and even incidents of death caused by PED’s.

However, what about athletes with Therapeutic Use Exemption’s (TUE’s) and may have to use drugs to help control their testosterone levels? Should they be an exception?

References:

Savulescu, J., Foddy, B. and Clayton, M. (2004). Why we should allow performance enhancing drugs in sport. [online] Available at: https://bjsm.bmj.com/content/38/6/666.info [Accessed 7 Nov. 2018].

BBC Sport. (2015). Doping in sport: What is it and how is it being tackled?. [online] Available at: https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/athletics/33997246 [Accessed 7 Nov. 2018].

Uyeno, G. (2016). 10 Biggest Doping Scandals in Olympics History. [online] Available at: https://www.livescience.com/55779-biggest-doping-scandals-in-olympics-history.html [Accessed 6 Nov. 2018].

Mayo Clinic. (2015). Doping: Do you know the facts about performance-enhancing drugs?. [online] Available at: https://www.mayoclinic.org/healthy-lifestyle/fitness/in-depth/performance-enhancing-drugs/art-20046134 [Accessed 4 Nov. 2018].

blog.name: unlevelplayingfield
blog.title: Unlevel Playing Field
blog.description: A sports-related blog curated by final year Sports Education students at Nottingham Trent University

title: The grass isn’t always greener
body:
Undoubtedly, abuse within sport is one of, if not the most important issue that has to be brought up and investigated, right?

Athlete abuse is not just about the physical circumstances of which can occur, but also psychologically, it can really do some damage to an individual’s health and well being. Abuse is not just a case of physicality, but also speech and in sport, there may be times were one comes across some sort of abuse from their coach without hypothetically realising. Sure, it is fair to say that in comparison to a couple of decades ago you do not come across newspaper headlines about existing abuse within sport, but to this day you still have people/former athletes coming out and expressing to the media about their unfortunate experiences within this factor and because of factors like this, we still need to take such an issue with a serious manner.


The people in this world who have regrettably had to go through some sort of abuse within sport whilst growing up have, without a doubt, been damaged mentally and emotionally which may potentially stick with them forever, whether they have opened up about their abuse or not. The athletes, or former, that have opened up about their experiences have really done a powerful job in doing so. This isn’t just in being brave and stepping forward to tell the world something which has forever dented them, but they are also helping the lives of others who may have been through something similar, but just haven’t had the ‘guts’ to speak out. This brings me to my argument. How many people out there are yet still to speak out about abuse? How many exactly are we talking about? Are there individuals out their within a sport that are a dangerous threat to society but we have no idea about?

Let’s focus more towards football and its grassroots level. Children under the age of eighteen tend to be the most vulnerable and in football, children start to develop their football skills from as young as four years of age. The football clubs which run to develop the standard in their respective community habitually have coaches working (or volunteering) of who normally is one of the athletes fathers. Football clubs should require all coaches to have FA Coaching Badge Level One in order to coach children under the age of eighteen. But how can we be sure that every ‘coach’ in the country has this requirement? This has to be a worrying factor for those involved in Grassroots football. ‘Coaches’ who have access to the children arguably have easy access to the younger ones and this in itself leaves a huge problem.


Furthermore, how do we even start to look further into clamping down athlete abuse at this level? Can it really be as easy as an organisation visiting football clubs around the country and examining the insights at their respective clubs in case there is abuse? Children can be so, so sensitive and such topics like this may not always bring out the truth. Children can be fearful or may be to ‘scared’ to speak out about something that may have occurred with them. Can you blame them though? If you look further into the picture, there are very few adults that have spoken out about their issues that occurred many years ago and this itself must of took them a lot of courage. So what right would we have if we were to just ask children directly about abuse? What would be the right way to go around this?

N0695049

References:

Gervis, M. and Dunn, N. (2004). ‘The Emotional Abuse of Elite Child Athletes by their Coaches’. Child Abuse Review. Vol.13: 215-223

Brackenridge, C., Bringer, J. and Bishopp, D. (2005). ‘Managing Cases of Abuse in Sport’. Child Abuse Review. Vol.14: 259-274

Acknowledgements:  

https://www.pexels.com/photo/man-crying-on-field-1277396/

https://www.flickr.com/photos/143386750@N08/44953346054/in/photolist-2bunDCA-dUFUDr-X4GSMj-k9gwi9-ZKYtFS-ffDvxR-fdcJq6-4TgHXm-shC16X-TF36PH-227pdSd-26pB7rg-NKgwRB-29xg1Mn-hccRQj-gfEqiy-diXnjF-bEd8tf-fmBt2g-eShYd5-Qfq9jh-eR5HaB-dkYPD6-6xJWsR-23A17af-8rit4i-261jT9L-dS9k9x-24nmmUW-fgeSF4-azCfJh-TSmwsL-dWdQYS-24kuhY5-7hMcG4-cPfUfj-hzieFc-QpndrC-NhJ4YR-5AW1vL-XzYiwP-2b1wnFn-a3vyCZ-XiwNPp-5XQcGK-Vqjwt2-29wSegL-bqN9eB-m1nsRg-6YZyNH

Gervis, M. and Dunn, N. (2004). ‘The Emotional Abuse of Elite Child Athletes by their Coaches’. Child Abuse Review. Vol.13: 215-223

Brackenridge, C., Bringer, J. and Bishopp, D. (2005). ‘Managing Cases of Abuse in Sport’. Child Abuse Review. Vol.14: 259-274

Acknowledgements:  

https://www.pexels.com/photo/man-crying-on-field-1277396/

https://www.flickr.com/photos/143386750@N08/44953346054/in/photolist-2bunDCA-dUFUDr-X4GSMj-k9gwi9-ZKYtFS-ffDvxR-fdcJq6-4TgHXm-shC16X-TF36PH-227pdSd-26pB7rg-NKgwRB-29xg1Mn-hccRQj-gfEqiy-diXnjF-bEd8tf-fmBt2g-eShYd5-Qfq9jh-eR5HaB-dkYPD6-6xJWsR-23A17af-8rit4i-261jT9L-dS9k9x-24nmmUW-fgeSF4-azCfJh-TSmwsL-dWdQYS-24kuhY5-7hMcG4-cPfUfj-hzieFc-QpndrC-NhJ4YR-5AW1vL-XzYiwP-2b1wnFn-a3vyCZ-XiwNPp-5XQcGK-Vqjwt2-29wSegL-bqN9eB-m1nsRg-6YZyNH

trail.content_raw:
Undoubtedly, abuse within sport is one of, if not the most important issue that has to be brought up and investigated, right?

Athlete abuse is not just about the physical circumstances of which can occur, but also psychologically, it can really do some damage to an individual’s health and well being. Abuse is not just a case of physicality, but also speech and in sport, there may be times were one comes across some sort of abuse from their coach without hypothetically realising. Sure, it is fair to say that in comparison to a couple of decades ago you do not come across newspaper headlines about existing abuse within sport, but to this day you still have people/former athletes coming out and expressing to the media about their unfortunate experiences within this factor and because of factors like this, we still need to take such an issue with a serious manner.


The people in this world who have regrettably had to go through some sort of abuse within sport whilst growing up have, without a doubt, been damaged mentally and emotionally which may potentially stick with them forever, whether they have opened up about their abuse or not. The athletes, or former, that have opened up about their experiences have really done a powerful job in doing so. This isn’t just in being brave and stepping forward to tell the world something which has forever dented them, but they are also helping the lives of others who may have been through something similar, but just haven’t had the ‘guts’ to speak out. This brings me to my argument. How many people out there are yet still to speak out about abuse? How many exactly are we talking about? Are there individuals out their within a sport that are a dangerous threat to society but we have no idea about?

Let’s focus more towards football and its grassroots level. Children under the age of eighteen tend to be the most vulnerable and in football, children start to develop their football skills from as young as four years of age. The football clubs which run to develop the standard in their respective community habitually have coaches working (or volunteering) of who normally is one of the athletes fathers. Football clubs should require all coaches to have FA Coaching Badge Level One in order to coach children under the age of eighteen. But how can we be sure that every ‘coach’ in the country has this requirement? This has to be a worrying factor for those involved in Grassroots football. ‘Coaches’ who have access to the children arguably have easy access to the younger ones and this in itself leaves a huge problem.


Furthermore, how do we even start to look further into clamping down athlete abuse at this level? Can it really be as easy as an organisation visiting football clubs around the country and examining the insights at their respective clubs in case there is abuse? Children can be so, so sensitive and such topics like this may not always bring out the truth. Children can be fearful or may be to ‘scared’ to speak out about something that may have occurred with them. Can you blame them though? If you look further into the picture, there are very few adults that have spoken out about their issues that occurred many years ago and this itself must of took them a lot of courage. So what right would we have if we were to just ask children directly about abuse? What would be the right way to go around this?

N0695049

References:

Gervis, M. and Dunn, N. (2004). ‘The Emotional Abuse of Elite Child Athletes by their Coaches’. Child Abuse Review. Vol.13: 215-223

Brackenridge, C., Bringer, J. and Bishopp, D. (2005). ‘Managing Cases of Abuse in Sport’. Child Abuse Review. Vol.14: 259-274

Acknowledgements:  

https://www.pexels.com/photo/man-crying-on-field-1277396/

https://www.flickr.com/photos/143386750@N08/44953346054/in/photolist-2bunDCA-dUFUDr-X4GSMj-k9gwi9-ZKYtFS-ffDvxR-fdcJq6-4TgHXm-shC16X-TF36PH-227pdSd-26pB7rg-NKgwRB-29xg1Mn-hccRQj-gfEqiy-diXnjF-bEd8tf-fmBt2g-eShYd5-Qfq9jh-eR5HaB-dkYPD6-6xJWsR-23A17af-8rit4i-261jT9L-dS9k9x-24nmmUW-fgeSF4-azCfJh-TSmwsL-dWdQYS-24kuhY5-7hMcG4-cPfUfj-hzieFc-QpndrC-NhJ4YR-5AW1vL-XzYiwP-2b1wnFn-a3vyCZ-XiwNPp-5XQcGK-Vqjwt2-29wSegL-bqN9eB-m1nsRg-6YZyNH

summary: Pues al final nos lanzamos al gym y ya el fin de semana para tareas, despejo y planes que iran  surgiendo 🤓🤓!!!! Es increible...
caption:
Pues al final nos lanzamos al gym y ya el fin de semana para tareas, despejo y planes que iran surgiendo 🤓🤓!!!! Es increible como tu cuerpo va tomando forma inteligentemente y a nivel de fuerza brutal🏋️🏋️. A los hombros le doy su peso moderado y aun asi los veo fuertes💪💪, intentare meterle un poco mas de fuerza a los brazos sabiendo que lesionarme no es lo correcto se que esta liebre puede😊😊.
Al tren inferior si que le doy su potencia adecuada😉🤩🍑.
.
.
Bueno familia viernazo de peliculas ahora a cenar se ha dicho😋😋. Dulze sueños😘😘.
#pareja #canal #youtube #alimentacion tacion #sport (en Almería, Spain)
https://www.instagram.com/p/Bp-YJRmgqId/?utm_source=ig_tumblr_share&igshid=lzmvbue60xav

blog.name: unlevelplayingfield
blog.title: Unlevel Playing Field
blog.description: A sports-related blog curated by final year Sports Education students at Nottingham Trent University

summary: Is gaining a positive social status and norms within society worth risking your own health?
title: Is gaining a positive social status and norms within society worth risking your own health?
body:
As many of us are aware, within sport athletes get praised by fans as much as they get criticised. This is linked to social status, norms and stigma that are associated with becoming a professional footballer.

Gaining social status as a footballer is harder than we think and it’s not just all down to talent. It is reliant on their mental strength because they need to perform on regular basis in front of a large crowd. From a young age of 18, we are forced to make a life choice; whether to go to university or get an apprenticeship. There is a huge amount of pressure on this choice. However, a footballer of the same age has perhaps more pressure, since they play surrounded by 50,000 fans; they are being observed and vulnerable to criticism which is based on every move that they make.

Therefore, most players that aim high and are willing to pay the price of putting their body on the line in order to gain their aspirational social status within the sport. Many football players who are willing to carry on playing with an injury are viewed the most courageous of players. Similarly, a returning from a serious injury is perceived as dedicated to their career and the sport.

On the other hand, under conformity is where a player will prioritise the health of their physical body and place that before the sport. As you can imagine ‘under conformity’ is stigmatised not just within football but within most sports.

Is it worth risking your own health just to gain ‘social status’?

Let’s say it’s not uncommon to suffer an injury and continue playing.

These are some examples:

  • Bert Trautmann was a goalkeeper who suffered an injury and continued playing. After the game, they found out that he broke his neck.          
  • Stuart Pearce was a player that broke his leg in the first half of a game and continued playing, even refusing to take his boot off because he was determined to play the second half. Six months after, he broke the same leg and refused to be stretchered off.          
  • Vincent Kompany sustained an injury after a collision with a goalkeeper. Even though the medical team examined him, he chose to continue the game. Afterwards, reports disclosed that he suffered a broken nose, a cracked eye socket and concussion.
  • Wilfried Bony, after being substituted on in the second half, landed awkwardly resulting in a torn anterior cruciate ligament. Consequently, he was forced to miss the rest of the season.

Even though there are rules that have been enforced to guarantee players safety, most players won’t stop playing due to their aspirations of gaining a high social status within the sport. Stuart Pearce (shown in the example) was nicknamed ‘Psycho’ by his fans which I believe proves that even though he was talented, his social status was gained by being madly courageous in the face of injury.

Would they have continued playing if it was a less pressurised match? Perhaps, a game in which there is a smaller audience and less pressure, a footballer may not have felt the burden to continue playing.

To conclude, injuries happen on a regular basis in sport. However, it seems that particularly in football, injuries are extremely common with players often making the injury worse by continuing to play. I believe that, the gambling phrase ‘when the fun stops… STOP’ can be taken on board in the football community.  Footballers should not gamble with their bodies, just to gain social status.

N0700186

References:

Bailey, M. (2018). Seeking perfection in front of 50,000 people: why football is a pressure cooker for mental health issues. [online] The Telegraph. Available at: https://www.telegraph.co.uk/men/thinking-man/seeking-perfection-front-50000-people-football-pressure-cooker/ [Accessed 7 Nov. 2018].

Eurosport UK. (2018). The football hard men who played on through horrendous injuries. [online] Available at: https://www.eurosport.co.uk/all-sports/the-football-hard-men-who-played-on-through-horrendous-injuries_sto4708599/story.shtml [Accessed 6 Nov. 2018].

Hughes, B., and Coakley, J. (1991). Positive Deviance among Athletes: The Implications of Over Conformity to the Sports Ethics. Sociology of Sport Journal 8 (4), 307-325.

Young, K., White, P. & McTeer, W. (1994). Body Talk- Male Athletes Reflect on Sport, Pain and Injury. Sociology of Sport Journal, 11, 175-194

Acknowledgements:

https://www.pexels.com/photo/adult-athlete-cramps-field-460550/

https://www.pexels.com/photo/adult-athlete-cramps-field-460550/

  • Stuart Pearce was a player that broke his leg in the first half of a game and continued playing, even refusing to take his boot off because he was determined to play the second half. Six months after, he broke the same leg and refused to be stretchered off.          
  • Vincent Kompany sustained an injury after a collision with a goalkeeper. Even though the medical team examined him, he chose to continue the game. Afterwards, reports disclosed that he suffered a broken nose, a cracked eye socket and concussion.
  • Wilfried Bony, after being substituted on in the second half, landed awkwardly resulting in a torn anterior cruciate ligament. Consequently, he was forced to miss the rest of the season.

Even though there are rules that have been enforced to guarantee players safety, most players won’t stop playing due to their aspirations of gaining a high social status within the sport. Stuart Pearce (shown in the example) was nicknamed ‘Psycho’ by his fans which I believe proves that even though he was talented, his social status was gained by being madly courageous in the face of injury.

Would they have continued playing if it was a less pressurised match? Perhaps, a game in which there is a smaller audience and less pressure, a footballer may not have felt the burden to continue playing.

To conclude, injuries happen on a regular basis in sport. However, it seems that particularly in football, injuries are extremely common with players often making the injury worse by continuing to play. I believe that, the gambling phrase ‘when the fun stops… STOP’ can be taken on board in the football community.  Footballers should not gamble with their bodies, just to gain social status.

N0700186

References:

Bailey, M. (2018). Seeking perfection in front of 50,000 people: why football is a pressure cooker for mental health issues. [online] The Telegraph. Available at: https://www.telegraph.co.uk/men/thinking-man/seeking-perfection-front-50000-people-football-pressure-cooker/ [Accessed 7 Nov. 2018].

Eurosport UK. (2018). The football hard men who played on through horrendous injuries. [online] Available at: https://www.eurosport.co.uk/all-sports/the-football-hard-men-who-played-on-through-horrendous-injuries_sto4708599/story.shtml [Accessed 6 Nov. 2018].

Hughes, B., and Coakley, J. (1991). Positive Deviance among Athletes: The Implications of Over Conformity to the Sports Ethics. Sociology of Sport Journal 8 (4), 307-325.

Young, K., White, P. & McTeer, W. (1994). Body Talk- Male Athletes Reflect on Sport, Pain and Injury. Sociology of Sport Journal, 11, 175-194

Acknowledgements:

https://www.pexels.com/photo/adult-athlete-cramps-field-460550/
trail.content:
As many of us are aware, within sport athletes get praised by fans as much as they get criticised. This is linked to social status, norms and stigma that are associated with becoming a professional footballer.

Gaining social status as a footballer is harder than we think and it’s not just all down to talent. It is reliant on their mental strength because they need to perform on regular basis in front of a large crowd. From a young age of 18, we are forced to make a life choice; whether to go to university or get an apprenticeship. There is a huge amount of pressure on this choice. However, a footballer of the same age has perhaps more pressure, since they play surrounded by 50,000 fans; they are being observed and vulnerable to criticism which is based on every move that they make.

Therefore, most players that aim high and are willing to pay the price of putting their body on the line in order to gain their aspirational social status within the sport. Many football players who are willing to carry on playing with an injury are viewed the most courageous of players. Similarly, a returning from a serious injury is perceived as dedicated to their career and the sport.

On the other hand, under conformity is where a player will prioritise the health of their physical body and place that before the sport. As you can imagine ‘under conformity’ is stigmatised not just within football but within most sports.

Is it worth risking your own health just to gain ‘social status’?

Let’s say it’s not uncommon to suffer an injury and continue playing.

These are some examples:

  • Bert Trautmann was a goalkeeper who suffered an injury and continued playing. After the game, they found out that he broke his neck.          
  • Stuart Pearce was a player that broke his leg in the first half of a game and continued playing, even refusing to take his boot off because he was determined to play the second half. Six months after, he broke the same leg and refused to be stretchered off.          
  • Vincent Kompany sustained an injury after a collision with a goalkeeper. Even though the medical team examined him, he chose to continue the game. Afterwards, reports disclosed that he suffered a broken nose, a cracked eye socket and concussion.
  • Wilfried Bony, after being substituted on in the second half, landed awkwardly resulting in a torn anterior cruciate ligament. Consequently, he was forced to miss the rest of the season.

Even though there are rules that have been enforced to guarantee players safety, most players won’t stop playing due to their aspirations of gaining a high social status within the sport. Stuart Pearce (shown in the example) was nicknamed ‘Psycho’ by his fans which I believe proves that even though he was talented, his social status was gained by being madly courageous in the face of injury.

Would they have continued playing if it was a less pressurised match? Perhaps, a game in which there is a smaller audience and less pressure, a footballer may not have felt the burden to continue playing.

To conclude, injuries happen on a regular basis in sport. However, it seems that particularly in football, injuries are extremely common with players often making the injury worse by continuing to play. I believe that, the gambling phrase ‘when the fun stops… STOP’ can be taken on board in the football community.  Footballers should not gamble with their bodies, just to gain social status.
